results.title: Hyper >> [games magazine] Issue 1, December 1993
results.creator_credit: Stuart Clarke, Phillip Keir and Otter Publishing
results.brief_description:
Hyper was a multi-platform Australian video game magazine. It was Australia’s longest running gaming magazine, published from 1993 to 2019.

In addition to coverage of current major video game systems and game releases, Hyper also covered anime, DVD movies, arcade and classic games, and featured interviews with industry professionals and articles on game-related content such as game classifications, computer hardware and video game music. Hyper also had a sister magazine, the PC gaming oriented PC PowerPlay. (citation from Wikipedia).

A digital version of the magazine can be found here: https://archive.org/details/hyper-001_20200724_0134/mode/2up
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stuart Clarke, Phillip Keir and Otter Publishing

results.title: Access Video 1973-1982
results.creator_credit: Helen Eisler and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
The results of a reserach project funded by the Australian Film Commission and the Commonwealth Employment Programme this title presents highlights of programmes of historical importance, demonstrating the growth and maturing of independent video which in turn reflects the development of community and political activity during the seventies.

During this decade 12 access video centres were established. This title shows highlights of proigrammes made by various centres.

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries
results.brief_description:
Venture into the opulent world of Melbourne in the 1920s and enjoy episodes of the ABC TV series ‘Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries’.

‘Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries’ focuses on the personal and professional life of Phryne Fisher (Essie Davis), a private detective in 1920s Melbourne.

This Australian television mystery drama is based on Kerry Greenwood’s ‘Phryne Fisher Murder Mystery’ novels and was created by Deb Cox and Fiona Eagger. Premiering on 24th February 2012 with the pilot episode ‘Cocaine Blues’, its popularity saw a third series produced and screened in May 2015.

constellations_other.name: Designing across eras and genres
constellations_other.description: Acclaimed costume designer Marion Boyce created this beautiful black satin dress and eggshell cape worn by Sarah Snook in The Dressmaker. Her designs nabbed her an AACTA for best costume design, but over her decades-long career, she's proved herself a versatile artist.

results.title: Stories of Rippon Lea Estate
results.brief_description:
Melbourne’s historic Rippon Lea Estate is one of the fabulous locations used in the popular ‘Miss Fisher’ television series. It has also been the venue for an exhibition of the costumes from the series.
Here, staff of the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), who manage the property, talk about its history, its use as a filming location, and the relationship between the producers of the series, the National Trust, and the enthusiastic audiences for the series who have also visited Rippon Lea and the exhibition.

results.title: Stories of Labassa
results.brief_description: The historic mansion ‘Labassa’ in Melbourne has seen many occupants and much activity in its more than 150 years of existence. Bronwyn Worrall, who manages the property for the community heritage organisation, the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), discusses the building’s history as a family residence, a home for ‘hippies’ in the 1970s and its use as a location for a number of films.

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Murder Under the Mistletoe (Series 02. Ep. 13)
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description: Phryne, Dot and Dr Mac happily accompany Aunt Prudence to a picturesque chalet to celebrate a white Christmas in July. The party arrives to find one of the residents dead – electrocuted while hanging festive lights. No more suspicious than the usual Miss Fisher investigation, until the body count starts to rapidly rise. Heavy snowfalls and harsh weather trap them all with a murderer in their midst – and any one of them the next victim. It’s a race against time for Phryne and Jack to hunt down the culprit – and restore enough Christmas joy to take full advantage should they find themselves standing under that bunch of that mistletoe! [Source: Every Cloud Productions]

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Murder on the Ballarat train  (Series 01. Ep. 02)
results.creator_credit: Kate Dennis, Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description: The glamorous Phryne Fisher (Essie Davis), accompanied by her maid Dot, decide to travel to the country by train to collect her new Hispano-Suiza motor car.The charm of rail travel soon evaporates though, when Phryne unexpectedly has to use her trusty pearl-handled pistol to save a young woman’s life and solve the disappearance of her fellow passenger’s mother. Her train trip derailed by a gruesome murder, Phryne speeds home in her Hispano-Suiza to her new abode in St Kilda where she works through the clues until she discovers her unassuming murderer. [Source: Every Cloud Productions]

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Hispano Suiza
results.creator_credit: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description:
Learn more about the luxury motor car that appears in the series, Phryne’s red ‘Hispano-Suiza’.
One of the luxury cars of the 1920s, the ‘Hispano-Suiza’ was favoured by royalty, film stars and moguls. The name means “Spanish Swiss”, but the car was manufactured in France, as explained by its owner, Bob, who spent twelve years restoring what had been “just a heap of rusty bits”. His successful restoration adds an authentic glamour to Phryne’s motoring.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Dead Air (Series 02. Ep. 11)
results.creator_credit: Catherine Millar, Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description: There’s a new wireless in the Fisher household – but there’s murder on the airwaves when Dot’s new favourite show is interrupted by an on air panic. The radio station’s bookkeeper and budding announcer is found choked to death but when Phryne gets involved, she finds Jack already undercover as the newsreader. In an ironic turnaround, Phryne is officially engaged to investigate the death - as Jack resorts to more clandestine investigative strategies. In the cut and thrust of the investigation, Dot suffers the terrible realisation that she doesn’t want to relinquish working for Miss Fisher when she marries and takes up her wifely duties. [Source: Every Cloud Productions]

results.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries: Costume Designer Marion Boyce
results.creator_credit: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
results.brief_description:
Meet Marion Boyce, costume designer for ‘Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries’ as she discusses some of the process involved in recreating the look and feel of the 1920s for the popular television series.
Boyce muses on the “sumptuous elegance” of fashion in the nineteen twenties, a period she describes as one of “extreme excess in a lot of ways …. they lived a lot with gay abandon”. She highlights the flattering silhouette bestowed by 1920s men’s fashion of the time, dwells lovingly on the exotic and embellished fabrics of the time, and talks about the use of original pieces - buckles, shoes, feathers and furs - to heighten the authenticity of the costumes.
results.title_for_label: Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries: Costume Designer Marion Boyce
results.creator_credit_for_label: Deb Cox, Fiona Eagger, Every Cloud Productions and Screen Australia
